body: Some of the neighbors had been heard to express the wish over the years that a divine hand would smite Yeung Sun Live Poultry. Clucking chickens went into its storefront. Dead ones came out, bound for Chinatown restaurants. So did blood, and entrails, and putrid odors that wafted past the fancy lofts and dark-wood bars of an up-and-coming
title: A Collapse At a Poultry Shop Exposes a Rift Among Neighbors

body: Another year down, another drop of the ball, another chance to get it all right. The parties of New Year's Eve are ostensibly the way to start another trip around the Sun with a burst of exuberance. But really New Year's Eve is a confessional, a way to scrape off the muck of the year that's ending with loud music, maybe some libations and a
title: Soundtracks For a Year's Last Parties

body: Recordings are forever. Concerts -- even in the era of YouTube and the tour-documentary DVD -- are fleeting experiences, subject to many nonmusical variables. But they can transform reputations and careers. Here the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times recap their most memorable performances of 2011, in order of importance. JON PARELES Jon
title: Onstage Memories

body: JON PAUL LUPO grew up not far away in Marine Park, but thinking back, he figures the most interaction he had with Sunset Park in those days was driving past it on the Gowanus Expressway. For his wife, Melanie, the area was even less familiar -- she is from South Dakota. Early this year, though, after more than a decade away from New York, Mr. Lupo
title: LIVING IN | SUNSET PARK, BROOKLYN; A Low-Slung District With a Very High Perch

body: The show did not pander, fans said. It did not condescend. It showed Brooklyn, they insisted, for what it was -- a place, apparently, with unlicensed private detective work, armies of baby strollers and a bearded superhero whose most salient superpower, acquired after a below-the-belt run-in with the third rail of a subway, cannot be described in a
title: Gathering to Mourn the End of a Show That Celebrated Brooklyn

body: 'A Christmas Carol, as Told by Charles Dickens (himself)' Jacob Marley, Ebenezer Scrooge's former partner and fellow tightwad, was ''as dead as a doornail,'' Charles Dickens wrote. In the ''Christmas Carol'' at Canal Park Playhouse, Marley is as dead as, well, a chair. Empty wooden chairs -- a Windsor and a half-dozen folding models -- become
title: Spare Times: For Children

title: Holiday Theater, in Three Flavors

title: LIVING IN | BENSONHURST, BROOKLYN; Accessible, From All 4 Corners of the World

body: AARON LEFKOVE was struggling to raise close to $200,000 to open a New England-style clam shack in a Gowanus, Brooklyn, storefront. Bank loans were out of reach. ''We didn't have the kind of collateral they wanted,'' said Mr. Lefkove, a 31-year-old punk rocker and publisher's copywriter, nostalgic for family visits to Bigelow's New England Fried
title: Selling the Pie, Piece by Piece

body: NEXT week the large-ensemble jazz composer Darcy James Argue and the graphic novelist Danijel Zezelj will be collaborating for four nights on ''Brooklyn Babylon,'' as part of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It is an hourlong performance involving an 18-piece band conducted by Mr. Argue, with nearly continuous animation and
title: Animation Joins Jazz At the Next Wave Festival

body: THEIR frames molder and peel in the city's musty depths. Hundreds -- perhaps thousands -- rest in haphazard jumbles, their surfaces pocked with rust, their tubes airless and stiffened by time. No firm numbers exist for how many bicycles sit abandoned in storage rooms around New York City. They decay uncounted in dim basements, mixing awkwardly with
title: SPOKES; Salvaging Abandoned Bikes, Making Room for Others

body: Every fall, thousands of upper-middle-class parents here awake in night sweats, overcome by the anxiety of trying to get their children into costly and prestigious preschools. To say this, of course, is to say something as obvious as ''pork chops cost more at Dean & DeLuca than they do at Key Food.'' Two years ago an entire documentary film,
title: BIG CITY; Burdening Children With a Flawed Policy

body: Warren Street between Bond and Nevins offers many of the things well-off buyers seek in Brownstone Brooklyn: a pastoral, leafy feel; long rows of 19th-century town houses; proximity to transportation and charming little restaurants; young families on the block. But the block also has something that those buyers have traditionally seemed to avoid:
title: THE APPRAISAL; In Brooklyn, A Quaint Block And a Symbol of Blight

body: THE story of Heather Chaplin and her loft in Park Slope, Brooklyn, started auspiciously. Ms. Chaplin, a writer, and her husband, Aaron Ruby, a graduate student in philosophy, had been a couple since 1993. title: HABITATS | PARK SLOPE, BROOKLYN; How to Tame a Loft: Add Lace, Talk Trollope

body: Melissa and Emily Elsen, two sisters from South Dakota, opened Four & Twenty Blackbirds, their pie and coffee shop in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn, with the expectation that they would serve about 10 pies a day. title: REMIX; Pie Squared

body: It was business as usual when I stopped at the Queens Central Library in downtown Jamaica the other morning. Visitors were nosing through racks of dog-eared best sellers, schmoozing near the circulation desk and peering into banks of computers on long tables in the lobby. Across the room, beneath ''Discover!'' in red lettering, light poured through
title: ARCHITECTURE REVIEW; New York's Public Architecture Gets a Face-Lift

body: DEAR DIARY: A drizzle is falling as we head uptown on the Eighth Avenue bus. A woman gets off and the doors close. A voice calls out in panic, ''She forgot her umbrella.'' A gentleman presses the tape, but the driver is concentrating on the changing light, so our good Samaritan thrusts the umbrella through the rubber seams of the door and tosses it
title: METROPOLITAN DIARY; A Good Samaritan Fumbles With an Umbrella

body: If drummers are the engines of jazz, then pianists are often its mapmakers. It's not just that they're the bandleaders and the composers; they're also the content providers, the song finders, the place setters. They're the ones with the strongest chordal instruments, the most powerful harmony machines; they bring in the most outside materials and
title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; New Pilots at the Keyboard

body: WHEN she and her husband moved out in 1980, Kathy LaPolla DeStefano was not at all happy with Williamsburg, Brooklyn. ''The neighborhood was starting to go down the toilet, honestly,'' Ms. DeStefano, 56, an elementary school teacher, said over the telephone from her home in Coconut Creek, Fla. ''There was a lot of drugs and crime. It was an unsafe
title: On Facebook, Neighborhoods as They Once Were

body: WHEN Mac Premo moved to a smaller Brooklyn art studio in March, he didn't have room for the yellowed baseball cards, old telephones, floppy disks and other ephemera he had been collecting for decades. title: Some People Can't Just Throw Stuff Out

body: LIKE most MetroCard-carrying New Yorkers, Sara Schwartz normally spends Saturday night flitting about the city. She arrived at a friend's apartment with reinforcements: cheese, prosciutto, bread, wine (she left the
title: A New York Calm Amid the Storm

body: Cursing Irene for blowing your second-to-last summer weekend? Don't pack up your sundresses and swim trunks just yet. There's still time to kick away those fallen limbs, wipe that rain from your eyes and plunge once more into the (cheap) events that have made us lazy, hazy and crazy (in a good way) this summer. The Museum of Modern Art may have
title: WEEKEND MISER; The Last Throes of Summer

title: LIVING IN | GREENWOOD HEIGHTS, BROOKLYN; The Sweet Smell of, Well, Sweets

body: An article last Sunday about the status of development along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn misidentified the location of a condominium building called Third and Bond. As an accompanying map and picture caption correctly noted, it is on Bond Street and Third Street, not Third Avenue.
title: CORRECTION

body: You may not own New York City, but walking up the middle of Park Avenue can make you feel as if you did. For the next three Saturdays, from 7 a.m. to 1 p.m., Park Avenue and its connecting streets from the Brooklyn Bridge to Central Park will be closed to all but walkers, cyclists, skaters and other motorless movers, courtesy of the New York City
title: Weekend Miser

body: WHEN a baby whale lost its way and wandered into the mouth of the Gowanus Canal in 2007, it was christened Sludgie the Whale. The name stuck. When Sludgie died after two days of rescue attempts, there was sadness but little surprise. Something from the natural world had found itself in one of the most unnatural places in the country. Over the
title: Gowanus: Big Development Can Wait

body: ROME FROM the golden age of neorealism to the firebrand provocations of Pier Paolo Pasolini, a wide swath of classic Italian cinema has concerned the plight of the downtrodden. This underdog empathy is the animating force behind the work of Pietro Marcello, one of the most striking new talents in contemporary Italian film. But while they continue a
title: Finding Poetry in a Couple's Pain

body: 'THE LITTLE FARM SHOW' Only a brave woman would denounce a McDonald's meal in a room full of children. But that's what Tannis Kowalchuk will do on Sunday at the Living Room, where she and Brett Keyser will perform ''The Little Farm Show.'' Children don't often consider where their food comes from, Ms. Kowalchuk said, ''and I want to propose that
title: Spare Times

body: The boat's captain was happy to clear up one misconception: Sewage does not necessarily stink. ''People think sewage is going to smell,'' the captain, John Lipscomb, said late Friday afternoon as he steered his boat closer to the disabled North River Wastewater Treatment Plant in Harlem. ''But this is feces and bathwater and dishwashing water. Part
title: On the Hudson, With the Water-Quality Mavens

body: Ambivalence about immigration is as American as, well, corned beef, pizza, knishes, black-eyed peas, empanadas -- and apple pie. Which is why ''Toward a Better Life: America's New Immigrants in Their Own Words -- From Ellis Island to the Present'' (Prometheus Books, $26) is a welcome reminder that the vast majority of today's newcomers are
title: BOOKSHELF; Giving Voice to Immigrants, Past and Present

body: Pop Ben Ratliff JAMES FALZONE is a tremendously likable, alert, no-nonsense improvising clarinetist from Chicago. He comes for a rare New York visit this week, and plays three nights in a row; see him while you can. Mr. Falzone's music is thoughtful and often quiescent, but he can play hard to the breaking point. He likes history, but he's not only
title: THE WEEK AHEAD | JULY 24-JULY 30

title: Weekend Miser

body: Lorraine Johnson says she remembers the garbage trucks that lined up near her housing project on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, to unload trash at a marine sanitation station on the East River. They made noise, spewed diesel fumes, attracted rats and smelled bad -- ''like dead bodies,'' she said. ''I have nightmares just thinking that there's a
title: In Fight Against Trash Station, Upper East Side Cites Injustice

body: Among the many possible ways of gauging a good time at the second annual Undead Jazzfest, which wound down in the wee hours of Monday morning, there are a few that seem truest to the spirit of the event. If you were there, you might rate your experience by answering the following questions: Did you feel like a part of something vital and collegial?

title: THE WEEK AHEAD | JUNE 26-JULY 2

author: Ava Chin writes the Urban Forager column for the City Room blog, at nytimes.com/cityroom.
body: EVER since I discovered mulberries growing in a park in Flushing, Queens, on the day of my grandmother's death two years ago, the delight of finding summer berries has been bittersweet for me. title: URBAN FORAGER; An Irresistible Berry (Within Limits)

body: Art Carol Vogel Although known as a German Expressionist and a central Bauhaus figure, LYONEL FEININGER was born in New York. He lived there until he was 16 and moved to Germany. title: THE WEEK AHEAD; June 26 -- July 2

body: Last October, just before the deal-making frenzy of the Frankfurt Book Fair, the indie publisher Johnny Temple received an e-mailed book proposal that he was tempted to brush off. title: A Heckuva Book Pitch. That's Putting It Mildly.

body: KIDSFILMFEST ''The Driving Accident'' may not sound like the kind of film you'd want to show children. body: HAVING lived primarily in postwar high-rises, Jordan Kingston envisioned a charming brownstone as her next home. An entire ground floor would be best, with a garden out back and a ''welcoming door that I could put a wreath on'' for the holidays, she said. But, after a few weeks of apartment-hunting, she and her husband, Michael, discovered that
title: THE HUNT; 'Something New and Sparkly'

body: EVERY now and then, it seems, some wistful city dreamer gets it into his head to resuscitate an old New York tradition and, before you know it, a newfangled speakeasy or a resurrected stickball league or an up-to-the-minute version of burlesque appears. At present, this seeming need for history has brought about a small rebirth of the classic New
title: In the Beefsteak Revival, Gluttony Is Good

author: Alec Appelbaum is writing a book about urban planning and climate change.
body: MANHATTAN'S street grid, which turned 200 years old last month, has long been an easy target for urban romantics. They love to point out how its relentless logic -- most blocks are a precise 200 feet by 600 feet -- imposed a soulless Cartesian order on a once-lush coastal island, trampling nature and leading to two centuries of real-estate mania.
title: OP-ED CONTRIBUTOR; New York's Green Grid

body: Because the Miser is almost as tired of hearing New Yorkers complain about these last lingering days of winter as she is of complaining about them herself, here are some events to provide a glimpse of hope, a light at the end of the wind tunnel that is 40th Street, a reminder that spring is on the way. title: Weekend Miser

body: Neighbors around the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn already know their waterway is a toxic soup of heavy metals, sewage and probable carcinogens. But some dream of treasures that might also be uncovered as a federal Superfund cleanup of the canal gets under way. Perhaps remnants of a tidewater mill dam? A few Indian arrowheads and fishing hooks?
title: At Gowanus Canal, Unearthing Pollutants, and Perhaps Treasures

title: Chinese Community Left Devastated After Bus Crash

title: Tenaciously Foul, And Getting A Good Flush

body: One late night in 2008, Lisa Dowda was waiting on an empty Brooklyn street for a bus home to Sunset Park. title: 'San Men': Portraits of the People Who Keep New York City Clean

body: For Joe Santos, producing and distributing his own gin was a way to say goodbye to the lock-step march of the corporate world and hello to creativity and originality. He wanted to give the gin a name that communicated that. So he invoked a certain New York City borough, the one currently outpacing the others in self-satisfaction. Brad Estabrooke
title: THE TIPSY DIARIES; Pride of Place In Every Drop
